Metadata: Identification of insulin-like growth factor-binding proteins in the circulation of four teleost fish species

The insulin-like growth factors (IGF-I and IGF-II) circulate bound to specific binding proteins (IGF-BPs). IGF-BPs are believed to play important roles in regulating IGF-I stimulated growth without the occurrence of insulin-like side effects, to increase the half-life of IGFs in the circulation, and to assist in the targeting of IGFs to their responsive tissues. This study reports that IGF-BPs were demonstrated in the circulation of four teleost fish species, coho salmon ("Oncorhynchus kisutch"), striped bass ("Morone saxatilis"), tilapia ("Oreochromis mossambicus"), and longjawed mudsucker ("Gillichthys mirabilis").
